content: Welcome! | Michael Oberst Welcome! Michael Oberst Assistant Professor of Computer Science, Johns Hopkins University Follow Baltimore, MD Email Twitter LinkedIn GitHub Iâ€™m an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Johns Hopkins, and a part-time Visiting Scientist at Abridge. Previously, I was a postdoc at Carnegie Mellon University, working with Zack Lipton, and completed my PhD in Computer Science at MIT working with David Sontag. My group develops machine learning and statistical methods for reliable decision-support in healthcare. Research Overview When can we rely on machine learning in high-risk domains like healthcare? My research focuses on two related challenges: The need for causal reasoning and robust performance. We often want to draw causal conclusions about the impact of ML deployments (e.g., will deploying an ML-based decision-support tool improve patient outcomes?). Moreover, we want our models to perform well across different hospitals and patient populations, including those that differ from the hospitals / populations seen during model development. These objectives complicate the development and validation of reliable models, as they run into limitations of what our data can tell us without further assumptions. For instance, in causal inference, we only observe outcomes for the treatments that were actually prescribed to patients, not all possible treatments. Similarly, we do not observe performance on every conceivable hospital where a model might be deployed, but only on the (typically much more limited) data we have access to. I approach these challenges using tools from causality and statistics, often incorporating external knowledge into the process of model validation and design.
